title: Heartland Collegiate Athletic Conference
text:
The Heartland Collegiate Athletic Conference (HCAC) is an intercollegiate athletic conference affiliated with the <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">NCAA</a>'s <a href="NCAA%20Division%20III">Division III</a>. Member institutions are located in <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a>, <a href="Kentucky">Kentucky</a> and <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a>. Founded as the Indiana Collegiate Athletic Conference (ICAC) in 1987, it reincorporated under its current name in 1998 with the addition of several schools from Ohio.
Original members of the HCAC included Anderson, Bluffton, Franklin, Hanover, Manchester, Mount St. Joseph, Wabash, and Wilmington. Of the ten current members, six were founding members of the former ICAC.
Former members include DePauw (1987-1998), Taylor (1988-1991), Wabash (1987-1999), and Wilmington (1998-2000). <a href="Rose%E2%80%93Hulman%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Rose–Hulman Institute of Technology</a> (1988-1998) re-joined as of July 1, 2006.
History.
The Indiana Collegiate Athletic Conference (ICAC) was formed in June 1987, with 1990–91 being the first full season of competition (all eight teams competing in eight varsity sports).
Charter members in 1987 included <a href="Anderson%20University%20%28Indiana%29">Anderson University</a>, <a href="DePauw%20University">DePauw University</a>, <a href="Franklin%20College%20%28Indiana%29">Franklin College</a>, <a href="Hanover%20College">Hanover College</a>, <a href="Manchester%20College%20%28Indiana%29">Manchester College</a>, and <a href="Wabash%20College">Wabash College</a>. <a href="Rose-Hulman%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology</a> and <a href="Taylor%20University">Taylor University</a> later joined in 1988.
The addition of three Ohio schools (<a href="Bluffton%20University">Bluffton College</a>, the <a href="Mount%20St.%20Joseph%20University">College of Mount St. Joseph</a>, and <a href="Wilmington%20College%20%28Ohio%29">Wilmington College</a>) and the departure of two Indiana schools (DePauw and Rose-Hulman) during the 1998–99 season prompted a change in name to Heartland Collegiate Athletic Conference. Wabash and Wilmington later departed in the 1998–99 and 1999–2000 seasons respectively. <a href="Transylvania%20University">Transylvania University</a> joined in 2001. Rose-Hulman re-joined the HCAC, effectively for the 2006–07 season.
The most recent expansion was when <a href="Earlham%20College">Earlham College</a> of <a href="Richmond%2C%20Indiana">Richmond, Indiana</a> was accepted as the 10th member of the conference in October 2009 to begin competition in the fall of 2010.
Member schools.
Current members.
All of the conference's members throughout its history have been private schools. All have a religious affiliation except current member Rose-Hulman and former member Wabash.
Sports.
Member teams compete in women's <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="cross%20country%20running">cross country</a>, <a href="golf">golf</a>, <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">soccer</a>, <a href="softball">softball</a>, <a href="tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> and <a href="volleyball">volleyball</a> and men's <a href="baseball">baseball</a>, <a href="basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="cross%20country%20running">cross country</a>, <a href="American%20football">football</a>, <a href="golf">golf</a>, <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">soccer</a>, <a href="tennis">tennis</a> and <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a>.
